where_to_read: Leaves of grass are all up in my stuff

reviews.review_text: It was interesting to read. Some info you don't read other places.
Marvelously fun read about our haunted Capitol building.

CAPITOL HILL HAUNTS - Tim KreppFor those of you that love ghost stories or who want to investigate our Nation's Capitol, Washington, D.C. this is the book for you. The author gives a detailed description of each building he has encounter by people who have experienced them. The intriguing background history and the story of the haunt are interesting lore.

Krepp is an excellent storyteller.  As a Capitol Hill resident I was intrigued by eerie tales of places I see all the time.  Visitors will like it as well… much better than a "same-old-thing" guidebook.
Great book from a wonderful DC tour guide, very informative and funny. Can't wait to go back to DC and check these haunts out.
Capitol Hill Haunts is a wonderful new,to me & hopefully you, way to explore our nations Capitol.  An engaging walk through our history with the people who made, and continue to make it.

Popular Washington DC blogger and tour guide Tim Krepp has written an engaging and informative book on things that go bump on Capitol Hill. The author places each spirit in its historical context so the reader learns history and chuckles too. I recommend this book to tourists, tour guides, historians and all those who love ghosts and ghoulies.

As someone who lived on Capitol Hill for ten years, this was a blast.  I can't wait for the sequel, presuming it's zombies or vampires, and still on Capitol Hill.  A must read for any local or tourist.

I really enjoy this book.  I live in this neighborhood and enjoy being able to point out places and stories to friends who come for a visit.  Any tour guide would be well served by the tidbits and anyone who enjoys local color gleaned through some amazing archival research should take note.  If you buy it you will not be disappointed

title: Capitol Hill Haunts (Haunted America)

summary:
From the Demon Cat that stalks the Washington crypt to the restless spirit of John Quincy Adams in Statuary Hall, it is no wonder that in 1898 the Philadelphia Press declared the Capitol to be the most thoroughly haunted building in the world. Yet there are as many ghosts in the neighborhood as there are beneath the dome.

Local writer and guide Tim Krepp intrepidly takes on the best-known haunted tales while also exploring the lesser-known specters. From the weeping lady of The Maples to Commodore Tingey, who still stands watch in the Navy Yard, to the dozens of famous ghosts hosted by Congressional Cemetery, many former residents seem bound to their old home. Join Krepp as he explores the most historic and hair-raising haunts of the Hill.

                    final fall
